Text: Needs a Body of Water[potrzebuje zbiornika wodnego]

ISA's Special Protocol
Maximum Security Authorization
Level: Omega
Codename: Killswitch
Order: 1K1K1
ij-78a9a6k0ba98
Ich wysokie temperatury powodują, że woda nigdy nie zamarza i pozwalają roślinom rosnąć przez cały rok..
Roślinność przystosowana jest do ich niskich temperatur, ale mimo to zimą pozostaje uśpiona.
Roślinność nie rośnie ze względu na niskie temperatury i stale zamarzniętą ziemię.
Odpowiednia temperatura dla roślin, ale niewystarczająca wilgotność, aby mogły rosnąć.
Warmer and wetter grounds where lichen can be abundant.
Warm temperatures and constant humidity that favors plants' growth.
Warm waters suitable for the development of cyanobacteria.
Humidity and temperature levels too low for plants to grow.
Humidity and temperatures with seasonal variations that affect lichen's growth.
Highly fluctuating annual temperatures that affect plants' growth.
Annual variations in water temperature that affect the growth of cyanobacteria.
High altitudes and low temperatures where no vegetation can grow.
Frozen temperatures and zero humidity, where no plant can grow.
Frozen waters not suitable for life.
Building Outside The Water Supply Network

Piaskownica pozwala na zabawę wszystkimi mechanizmami gry we własnym czasie i na warunkach. Nie musisz nawet terraformować Marsa, jeśli tego nie chcesz.
Znajdź sposoby na przetestowanie wszystkich technologii. Lub szukaj kreatywnych i nowatorskich form, aby poszerzyć kolonie i uczynić je bardziej wydajnymi. I podejmij to wyzwanie zalecane dla doświadczonych graczy.
Masz całą planetę, aby podnieść swoją kreatywność na nowy poziom!

W trybie fabularnym wcielasz się w zaawansowaną sztuczną inteligencję, której głównym zadaniem jest terraformowanie Marsa. Ale życie to nie tylko bycie mądrym. Dotyczy to również tych, z którymi nawiązujesz więź oraz tego, jak Twoje decyzje zbliżają Cię lub oddalają od nich.
Podążaj własną ścieżką i odkryj, co Cię czeka na końcu tej ekscytującej historii.
Aha, a kiedy skończysz, bądź dobrym graczem i nie psuj zakończeń! ;)

Sztuczna inteligencja, która może naśladować ludzką inteligencję i zachowanie. Jesteś więcej niż zdolny do wykonania każdego powierzonego ci zadania, ale masz pewne trudności w radzeniu sobie z surowymi realiami środowiskowymi. W związku z tym koszty i czas budowy są zmniejszone, podobnie jak tempo niszczenia budynku. Dodatkowo na planecie można znaleźć więcej zasobów naturalnych.

Jesteś sztuczną inteligencją zdolną do interpretowania modeli i instrukcji. W zwykłym środowisku możesz rozwiązać dowolne przydzielone Ci zadanie. Tak więc wszystko zostanie znormalizowane dla prawidłowego funkcjonowania: od kosztów i czasu budowy, po ilość zasobów na planecie, a także ogólną szybkość zużycia budynków.

Jesteś sztuczną inteligencją, która pod każdym względem przewyższa ludzi, co również spowodowało, że słusznie rozwinąłeś kompleks wyższości. Musisz stawić czoła naprawdę wrogiemu środowisku. Tak więc koszt i czas budowy oraz zużycie budynku będą wysokie. Zasobów będzie mało, a rozbierając budynki, odzyskasz mniej zasobów.

Witamy w demie Per Aspery.
Pełna wersja zawiera pełną kampanię ekscytującego podboju Marsa przez ludzkość. To demo zawiera zajawkę do aspektów symulacji Per Aspera. Odwiedź naszą stronę Steam, aby uzyskać najnowsze aktualizacje, przedyskutować swoje wrażenia i, co najważniejsze, nacisnąć przycisk listy życzeń!

To demo daje przedsmak historii i poprowadzi Cię przez pierwsze kroki w budowaniu własnej małej kolonii na czerwonej planecie, jednocześnie radząc sobie z surowością środowiska.

Odwiedź naszą stronę Steam, aby kupić pełną wersję gry i podziel się swoimi doświadczeniami z tysiącami graczy.
Witamy w Per Aspera – wersja demo

New DLC and saved games compatibility

Soon we will be launching Green Mars, a free DLC which will include many new buildings and improvements to the flora & fauna systems. It will be incompatible with your current saved games, but you will be able to continue your progress from the v.1.4 branch.

For more information, click here. And THANK YOU for your support!

Harvest time has finally come.
Green Mars is here!

This DLC introduces new mechanics that significantly change the gameplay during stage four of the terraforming plan: Green Mars. These changes are incompatible with your current saved games, so a new game must be created in order to play it.

In case you want to keep playing your saved games, switching back to the previous branch is super easy!

1. Find “Per Aspera” in your Steam Library and access its properties by right-clicking and selecting “Properties”.
2. Navigate to the “betas” sub-menu.
3. In the drop-down menu, select the “v.1.4.5” branch.
4. That’s it! Your game should begin with the old version.

1. Find “Per Aspera” in your GOG Galaxy Library, then, next to the “Play” button, access the “More” drop-down menu.
2. In the “More” menu, go to “Manage Installation” and left-click “Configure”.
3. Open the "Beta Channels" drop-down menu.
4. Select the “v.1.4.5” branch.
5. That's it! You will have successfully switched to v.1.4.5 and will be able to continue your previous savegames.

The memory file you are trying to load is not compatible with the current game version. You will have to switch back to a previous version to keep playing it.
If you need help on how to change versions, check the instructions in the Patch Notes on the main menu.

A mode that helps you learn to play Per Aspera and lets you experience the story without presenting too big of a challenge. Recommended for players who have never played a simulation or city builder game before.

Abundance of natural resources.

Much lower resource costs, construction time, and decay rate of structures.

Significantly faster and more durable workers.

Extra tips for learning how to play.

A way to fulfill the dream of conquering Mars without suffering the hostility of its environment. Recommended for new Per Aspera players who are familiar with this genre.

More natural resources.

Lower resource costs, construction time, and decay rate of structures.

Increased worker speed and durability.

The real terraforming experience. This level will test your skills as a player but allow you to advance at a steady pace. Recommended for players who are experienced with Per Aspera or this genre.

Average amount of natural resources.

Average resource costs, construction time, and decay rate of structures.

Average worker speed and durability.

An extra harsh Martian environment only the brave dare try to conquer. This challenge is for highly skilled Per Aspera players looking to test the limits of their abilities.

Limited amount of natural resources.

Higher resource costs, construction time, and decay rate of structures.

Reduced worker speed and durability.

Limited resource recovery from scrapping.

A mode that lets you terraform Mars without presenting too much of a challenge. Recommended for players who have never played a simulation or city builder game before.

Abundance of natural resources.

Much lower resource costs, construction time, and decay rate of structures.

Significantly faster and more durable workers.

This save file requires from you to buy the Blue Mars DLC.
Grab a copy and start enjoying a new refreshing experience!
Alert! The Base Is Under Attack
The colonies are under attack. Activate the Security and Defense Protocol to deploy military units.
Buildings are experiencing critical failure. Check if enough maintenance drones are assigned to the area.
A building has lost power. Build a power source nearby to restore functionality.
A building is not connected to the power grid. Add a power building nearby.
A building is not connected to the water supply network. Use water booster pumps to reach the building.
Workers cannot reach the assigned target. Build a worker hub to connect the distant building.
An asteroid impact is imminent. Take precautions to reduce damage.
Colonies are suffering from starvation. Prioritize food production to keep colonists alive.
A research project has been completed. Select a new technology to initiate research.
A new special project is ready to be deployed. Certain projects require an available spaceport to initiate.
Congratulations! A directive is now complete. The next steps will be displayed on-screen.
New colonists have arrived on Mars. Ensure enough space is available in the colonies.
An abandoned facility has been detected. Build a research outpost to investigate.
A new resource vein has been detected. Build a mine to extract materials.
Congratulations! A new resource has been discovered.
Congratulations! A new building type is available for construction.
An incoming call is pending. Open the dialogue panel to receive it.
Individualize the district by changing its name
This building isn't connected to any other aquatic structure.

Congratulations! The first spaceport is ready for use. Zoom out to the Orbital View to assign and manage special projects.

You can choose special projects to research in your Tech Tree. Once selected, colonists will investigate a technology until it's complete. Then you can assign it to an available spaceport to kick it off.

These projects will be the key to a successful terraformation of Mars. Keep up the good work!
Congratulations, you have won the game
And just like that, Mars collected another ruin in its surface.

Congratulations! The first colonists have arrived. Make sure they have enough water, food, and shelter to survive on Mars.

It is the duty of the colonists to provide technical assistance to this project. When satisfied, they will be able to focus on their research projects, advancing the technologies required to fulfill the mission.

Colonists will migrate internally using purpose-built Airships to the most efficient colonies and research outposts. And, in the event of starvation, they may eventually return back to Earth for safety.

Take also into consideration that the number of colonists can naturally increase or decrease from time to time, as some of them may have children or peacefully decay on the planet.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! You can now build worker factories and worker hubs. Worker factories will produce new workers.

Each worker requires a vacant worker hub. Areas are automatically assigned around occupied worker hubs. Workers will serve primarily the buildings in their assigned area, but also will pick up or leave resources in neighboring buildings.

Use the Traffic Lens to check out the assigned areas. Add more worker hubs to your network if worker areas are too busy. Your worker factories will create new workers as long as they have the required resources, and there are vacant hubs.

Keep up the good work!

Congratulations! You have unlocked the water treatment and packing plants, and the water booster pumps. Now you can create the first water supply network on Mars.

Until now, you only produced water from ice, but this technology will allow you to collect water from bodies of water and distribute it to your farms, biodomes, and cities.

These structures require a certain amount of running water to function. Connect them to your water treatment plants through pipes. If a structure is too far away, extend your network using the water booster pumps.

Your water packing plants will convert running water into ice, facilitating the supply of basic colonies and food factories in the later stages of the terraforming plan.

Congratulations! The domed farms you have unlocked will produce food for the colonies, although they must be placed on an adaptable craters. They require to be connected to the water supply network to operate as expected. Connect them to your water treatment plants through pipes, or in case they are too far away, use the water booster pumps to extend the network.

Check out that the running water is being distributed to all these farms, the biodomes and cities by using the Water Lens.

Congratulations! You have unlocked the organic material dumpster. This building will be very useful to keep your plants constantly growing, which in turn will boost the conversion of CO2 into O2.

Photosynthesis, which is when plants consume CO2 from the air and release O2, is more intense when they are growing. If you build these dumpsters near the plant-covered areas, they will shorten their life cycle, and consequently they will increase the amount of oxygen in the air.
Melt The Dry Ice Polar Caps

Congratulations! You are about to start the terraforming plan. The first stage consists of liberating all the CO2 that is trapped as CO2 ice in the polar caps of Mars. This can be done in multiple ways, and through different special projects. Check the Tech Tree to learn more about how they work.

During this stage, the CO2 in the caps will start sublimating, and further increasing the planet's temperature, creating a runaway effect until the caps disappear completely.

· Raise the temperature to -50°C.
· Sublimate the frozen CO2.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! The CO2 trapped in the polar caps of Mars has been liberated.

The conditions are ripe for stage 2. Create an atmosphere by realising the CO2 trapped in the regolith.

· Raise the pressure to 300 mbar.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! The CO2 trapped in the regolith has been freed, increasing the planet's atmosphere and temperature, which in turn have increased the amounts of liquid water.

The conditions are ripe for stage 3. Elevate the planet's temperature by reaching 1 millibar of oxygen, and raise water stock to 400 meters.

· Raise the temperature to 0°C.
· Raise O2 levels to 1 mbar.
· Raise water stock to 400 meters.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! The planet's temperature has reached 0 Celsius, and the level of oxygen is at least at 1 mbar.

The conditions are ripe for stage 4. Allow the presence of more sophisticated life forms by increasing O2 to 120 millibars.

Oxygen levels above 30% means high flammability risk. Introduce a buffer gas (Nitrogen) into the atmosphere to keep the oxygen level low.

· Raise O2 to 120 mbar.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! O2 has been further increased to at least 120 millibars, leading to the development of more sophisticated life forms.

The conditions are ripe for stage 5. Create a breathable atmosphere by balancing the CO2 and O2 levels.

Remember to keep the oxygen concentration below 30% at all times by releasing Nitrogen into the atmosphere.

· Lower CO2 levels to 5%.
· Lower O2 levels to 30%.
· Build an artificial magnetosphere.

Keep it up with the plan, and terraform Mars!

Congratulations! CO2 levels are less than 5 percent of the atmosphere, and the O2 is under 30 percent, enabling the colonists to be in the open without spacesuits.

The prime directive has been completed!
Thanks for playing the PER ASPERA preview!
The full version will be available on Steam by the end of the year. Add the Per Aspera to your wishlist and get notified of our latest news!

We hope you had as much fun playing it as we had making the game.

Keep your saves and carry over your progress into the main game by visiting our Steam store page and purchasing the full version, in which you will also be able to:

· Explore your creativity to terraform Mars with the Sandbox Mode.
· Immerse yourself in a science fiction mystery story.
· Develop new technologies based on real-world science.
· And defend your colonies from unknown and combative forces.

We believe that your experience in Per Aspera is invaluable and can help us improving the game.
That's why we are asking you to share ANONYMOUSLY some game data. This data will contribute to game balance, bug fixing, and quality of life improvements.
We will NOT have access to your IP, or any other way to identify particular users, and the studio will never share that data externally.
To read the full terms, <u>please click here</u>
We will never use your data for any other reason beyond game improvements.
You can change this setting anytime from the OPTIONS window
Welcome to Mars! From the right sidebar of your screen, you can select buildings to place on the planet. Or you can left-click on a resource to select the building directly from the pop-up menu.

• Building Limit +100

Tip: In the structure counter at the bottom left of the screen, you can open a board with all your buildings. Among other things, the table allows you to locate a specific structure, or select a group of a particular type of buildings, turn them on/off or prioritize them.

Incoming meteors showers may destroy your buildings. If you do not rebuild them, they will be eventually scrapped. Left-click on a destroyed building to select the option to rebuild it. Or rebuild multiple buildings at once by holding Shift and drawing a selection box with the mouse or hold Ctrl and select one by one.

Introduce genetically altered lichen that can convert CO2 into O2.

• Biodome
• Bioengineered Lichen

Tip: Biodomes will function best in areas with enough temperature, humidity, and oxygen.

You've built your first areological scanner! Open the Scanner lens to see the scanned areas. Building more scanners will reveal resources faster. See the resource clusters on the planet by zooming out while using the scanner lens.

Congratulations! You have unlocked a new type of farms. Open farms consume running water and produce food for you colonies as other farms, but they do not require an adaptable crater for their construction.

These farms will spawn open-sky crop fields up to the maximum allowed by the arable land that surrounds them. They connect to other buildings using country roads which do not disturb the spawning of cultivated fields.

They need to be connected to the water supply network in order to work properly. Make sure to expand your network to reach them.

Congratulations! You can now build structures on Mars' bodies of water. This will allow you to research flooded special sites and mine underwater veins.

Shipyards and ports can be placed on coastlines. Shipyards produce ships which dock at ports. Resources are delivered by land to ports and then can be taken by the ships to construct and maintain structures on the water.

Only some of the land buildings have floating equivalents that can be built on Mars. In particular, you will need to expand the power network over the water using Wind Farms. Structures on the water have an additional resource cost.

Mars poles have been melted and that's just the first step in this transformative journey.

Thank you for playing through our Vertical Slice till the end! We sincerely hope you've enjoyed it.

Ad Astra!

Another methane asteroid is available for aerobraking. Once every couple decades or so, astronomers find another suitable methane asteroid to aerobrake. You can assign a spaceport to it in the special projects menu.

Another ice asteroid is available for aerobraking. Ice asteroids are fairly common, but only every decade or so do astronomers find a suitable one to aerobrake. You can assign a spaceport to it in the special projects menu.

Another nitrogen asteroid is available for aerobraking. A nitrogen asteroid is a rare find for astronomers, but they have found an aerobraking candidate close by. You can assign a spaceport to it in the special projects menu.

As you raise the temperature on Mars, ice veins in areas above 0 degrees will melt and lose stock over time.

Each unit of ice that melts increases the planetary water level by a tiny amount. Ice consumed by your buildings also increases the water level, while water packing plants reduce the level by the same amount.

As the ice veins deplete and the water level increases, you will need to transition from using ice veins to supply your colonies to using a water supply network that utilizes Mars' oceans.
Maintain Structural Integrity to upkeep production levels. Maintenance drones are required to repair buildings.
Measures building output compared to its maximum output.
Shows the number of resources that are pending delivery, in each hub's sector.
Shows the number of buildings maintained and the total load in this sector. All maintenance drones are shared within each sector.
Shows the number of colonists in this colony. Also shows how many are incoming or willing to leave.
Shows the number of sectors scanned by this scanner. Also shows the progress and ETA of the current scan.
Shows stored resources and maximum capacity of this building.

Stores customized quantities of selected resources, adjustable in steps of 10 units up to the maximum total allowed.

Shows resources needed to start construction.
The polar caps are rich in frozen CO<sub>2</sub>. Sublimate these caps to pressurize the atmosphere.
Atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> must increase to sustain more complex forms of life.
Atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> must be kept under 30%. Higher levels carry a serious flammability risk.
Atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> must be lowered to 5% or less for humans to breathe. As for animal life, it requires levels below 100 mbar, although larger animals need less than that.
Atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> must be lowered to 5% or less for humans to breathe. As for animal life, it requires levels below {0}, although larger animals need less than that.
A magnetic shield is required to protect life forms from solar radiation.
The different gases used to thicken the Martian atmosphere add to the planet's base temperature.
The frozen carbon dioxide trapped in the poles is released into the atmosphere, accelerating the warming process.
The greenhouse effect leads to an increase in the average surface temperature.
Space mirrors concentrate sunlight and redirect it to the planet's surface, heating the atmosphere.
Comets rich in nitrogen or CO<sub>2</sub> that crash into the planet's surface can increase its temperature.
Deimos is rich in carbonaceous material, which can help increase Mars' temperature.
Mars’ atmosphere is made up of a variety of gases like argon and carbon dioxide, and some trace amounts of oxygen and water.
In order to raise the planet's pressure, the atmosphere needs to be dense enough, and contain greenhouse gases.
A life-supporting atmosphere needs to contain a "buffer gas", such as nitrogen, which is vital for plants' photosynthesis.
Carbon dioxide traps solar radiation and builds a thicker Martian atmosphere.
High levels of oxygen in the atmosphere can raise the temperature but also carry a serious flammability risk.
High ozone concentrations contribute to raising the planet's temperature, as well as filtering solar radiation.
The percentage of the total surface of the planet that is occupied by the lichen, plants and cyanobacteria ecosystems.
Lichen can grow in extreme conditions making it perfect at surviving on Mars.
If the humidity and temperature levels are right, the plants will grow and thrive on Mars.
Cyanobacteria, commonly known as blue-green algae, have the ability to thrive in extreme conditions like those on Mars.
The larger the built-up areas, the less Martian surface will be occupied by flora.
A breathable atmosphere on Mars requires a balanced gas exchange, so both humans and plants can thrive.
Lichen uses photosynthesis to turn CO<sub>2</sub> into O<sub>2</sub>.
As they grow, plants turn the CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere into O<sub>2</sub>.
O<sub>2</sub> is a waste product of the photosynthesis carried out by cyanobacteria ecosystems.
The terraforming plan includes buildings that produce and capture O<sub>2</sub>, altering the amount of it present in the atmosphere.
To change language, go to the main menu
Measures the amount of liquid water in equivalent meters.
Select a technology to close the panel
This lens shows the service area of each worker hub, its workload, and the road traffic.
This lens shows the power generation buildings, and which other buildings are being supplied by them.
This lens shows the structural integrity of the buildings, along with the number of maintenance drones and facilities available per area.
This lens shows the scanned sectors, the mines' location and their reserves, and, from the Orbital View, the global resource clusters.
This lens shows the temperature ranges for the entire planet.
This lens shows the different biomes currently present on Mars.
This lens shows the direction and intensity of winds, as well as the air humidity.
This lens shows the protection area of each drone hive, the location of the swarms, and the overall status of the battle.
This lens shows the different districts and their boundaries.
The current special project the spaceport is developing.
Shows the in-transit resources, as well as the stock produced for the building.
Turns on the building, consuming power and making it operative.
Prioritizes the attention the workers will give to the building regarding the needed inputs and its priority in the power grid.
Upgrades the building to a more efficient version of itself. Costs resources and the building will be inoperative during the upgrade.

Will upgrade all the roads between the starting building and its destination. It costs resources.
The progress will be started when a worker is available, but the way will remain usable during the process.
Upgrades all the selected buildings by consuming resources.
Upgrades the roads that connect all the selected buildings by consuming resources.

Connects an hyperloop terminal to another one. Costs resources.
The Hyperloop will be usable when the connection ends.
Rebuilds the building. The cost of the building will be the same as if it were new.
Scraps the current building and returns the resources used on it.
Discards completely the building. No resources will be recovered.
Cancels the upgrading process of the building. The building will become operative immediately.
If ON, will automatically renew the special project assigned to the spaceport.
In addition to indicating in which direction the north pole of Mars is located, it allows access to the Orbital Screen from which all the special projects are managed.
Assigns the Spaceport indicated on the left to this project. It can be assigned to this project as many Spaceports as are available, deducting the cost of the project for each one of them.
Shows the number of launches required to complete this special project. The spaceport will automatically reassign itself when the current launch is finished until the special project is completed.
Each slider will determine the general priority of resources that an aspect of the logistic network will have, prioritizing the ones with a higher percentage over those with lower values.
Shows the height of each point in the map.
Shows the number of resources that are pending delivery, in each hub's sector.
Shows the traffic saturation of each road.
Shows the structural integrity of each building.
Shows the areas that are currently being defended by Hives.
This action will select all swarms in an area. The selected swarms will operate as different entities until they reach a target and then collapse into one swarm.
Will add new swarms to the current selection on an individual basis.

On a position or target, will pop up a slider to choose the number of assault drones that will go to that destination. Move your pointer left or right to move the slider. The remaining assault drones will remain on the original swarm.
Closes this popup and opens the technology tree window.
Closes this popup. You can always assign a technology to research later.
This opens the Terraforming Plan screen.
Shows the number of buildings grouped inside this district.
Shows the population currently living in the district.
Shows the number of workers and worker hubs in a given district.
Centers the camera over the district.
Opens the panel to rename the district.
Changes the color assigned to the district.
Districts are automatically generated, grouping buildings together and managing them from this panel.
Turns the district on or off. Also, when the building is not operative, the district is automatically deactivated.

Building Outside The Water Supply Network

The memory file is not compatible with the current game version. You will have to switch back to a previous version to load it.
None of these memory files are compatible with the current game version. Switch back to a previous version to load them.
The sky is generally clearer in this season, the second-longest since Mars makes a long journey on its eccentric elliptical orbit.
The dustiest semester of storms begins with this season, the second-shortest since Mars travels a short distance on its eccentric elliptical orbit.
Mars is closest to the sun at this time, and the southern hemisphere is tilted towards it, which makes this the hottest season.
Mars is farthest away from the Sun, and the southern hemisphere is tilted against it, which leaves the South pole in total darkness.
Regulates AMI's perception of time. Pause, speed up or slow it down using 0-5 keys (Default Settings).
At this speed, the simulation pauses but clicking on buildings, resources, or other items still opens their pop-up menu.
At this speed, 1 Sol equals 10 seconds and represents real-time.
At this speed, 1 Sol equals 5 seconds, which allows paying attention to daily tasks or small events even though time passes faster.
At this speed, 1 Sol equals 2.5 seconds, convenient to carry out both short and long-term terraforming tasks.
At this speed, 1 Sol equals 1.25 seconds and significantly speeds up several long processes.
At this speed, 1 Sol equals 0.625 seconds which allows fast jumping to the end of exceptionally long processes and projects.
Expands or collapses the list of special projects showing more or less information about them.
Shows the Spaceports available for assignment.
Shows the Spaceports assigned to ongoing special projects.

No entries available at this time.
The amount of dust in the Martian atmosphere increases during seasonal dust storms. But even in good weather, there's enough present to create its characteristic reddish sky.
Mars is home to Olympus Mons, the tallest mountain in the solar system. It's over 11 km (7 miles) higher than Mount Everest.
Mars has about a third of the Earth's gravity. That means you could jump three times higher.
It takes Mars 37 minutes longer to rotate than Earth.
Phobos is estimated to crash into Mars within 50 million years. It will either collide, or be scattered as a ring around Mars.
Mars' signature red is due to oxidation of its iron regolith. However, how it was oxidized is still a mystery, since there's virtually no oxygen in the atmosphere.
Since Mars is visible on Earth to the naked eye, no one is credited with its discovery.
Mars has seasons like Earth. However, they're twice as long due to Mars' longer orbit of the Sun.
When Mars is closer to the Sun, there are more dust storms on the planet.
Mars' potato-shaped moons, Phobos and Deimos, were named after the sons of Ares, the Greek god of war.
Lowlands dominate Mars' northern hemisphere, whereas highlands make up its southern hemisphere.
Valles Marineris is nearly four times deeper and longer than the Grand Canyon.
Mars is theorized to have had oceans covering up to a third of its surface.
On Mars, the Sun appears at about half the size as it does on Earth.
In 1877, astronomer Giovanni Schiaparelli discovered “canalis” on the surface of Mars. For some time, it was believed they were made by living creatures.
Mars’ core is very dense and theorized to be made up of iron, nickel, and sulfur.
Earth and Mars are the only planets in the solar system with polar ice caps. (Sorry, Pluto!)
Landing on Mars has been nicknamed the "seven minutes of terror", due to the many spacecrafts that crashed during the EDL stage.
